conclusion: Analyze the motion of the slider and the ball in each segment of the track using conservation of energy and momentum.
The slider starts from rest at point P and slides down the inclined track AB with an inclination angle θ = 37°.
The length of the inclined track is L = h/sin 37°.
The work done by gravity is mgh, and the work done by the frictional force is -μ mg cos 37° · L.
Using the work-energy theorem, the kinetic energy at the bottom of the inclined track is 1/2 mv_A^2 = mgh - μ mg · h/0.6.
The slider and the ball collide elastically on the horizontal track BC.
By conservation of momentum: mv_A = mv_{A1} + mv_{B1}.
By conservation of kinetic energy: 1/2 mv_A^2 = 1/2 mv_{A1}^2 + 1/2 mv_{B1}^2.
Solving the equations, v_{A1} = 0 and v_{B1} = v_A.
The ball moves on the circular track CD and then on the circular track DEF.
The minimum speed required to just pass the highest point E is v_E = sqrt(gR).
Using conservation of mechanical energy: 1/2 mv_F^2 = 1/2 mv_E^2 + mg(2R).
At the highest point E, mg = mv_E^2/R.
Substituting v_E into the energy equation: v_F = sqrt(6gR).
The ball leaves the track DEF with velocity v_F and lands at point Q on the ground.
The vertical component of the velocity is v_{Fy} = v_F sin θ and the horizontal component is v_{Fx} = v_F cos θ.
The time of flight is determined by the vertical motion: t = sqrt(2H/g).
